caption_text: The mechanism in Fig. 1 includes RRD steps as an avenue for initiation, hydrogen transfer from free radicals via RHT and from direct addition of H atoms, and isomerization reactions in- volving secondary dodecylpyrene radicals. As we will show in a subsequent section, including the hydrogen transfer steps is essential for modeling DDP pyrolysis whereas the pyrolysis of long-chain alkylbenzenes could be fully described without hydrogen transfer reactions. RATE CONSTANT ESTIMATES The previous section presented the reaction mech- anism for DDP pyrolysis.

caption_text: The maximum rate in Fig. 3 occurs at a DDP conversion of 0.18. For the DDP pyrolysis simulations at 425 C, the maximum occurred at a conversion of 0.10, and for the simula- tions a 375 C the maximum occurred at a conversion of about 0.20. Having demonstrated that the detailed chemical kinetic model for DOP is largely consistent with the neat pyrolysis results, we next explore the ability of the reaction model to predict the effect of the initial concentration on flOP pyrolysis.

Having demonstrated that the detailed chemical kinetic model for DOP is largely consistent with the neat pyrolysis results, we next explore the ability of the reaction model to predict the effect of the initial concentration on flOP pyrolysis.

caption_text: Inspection of Fig. 4 shows that the model captured the major trends in the data. These trends are a precipitous decrease in the flOP yield and an accompanying increase in the dodecane yield at high concentrations and a max- imum in the methylpyrene yield at an intermediate concentration. In addition to capturing the qualitat- ive trends in the data, the model also provided good quantitative predictions of the dodecane and methyl- pyrene molar yields.
raw_window: Inspection of Fig. 4 shows that the model captured the major trends in the data.

These trends are a precipitous decrease in the flOP yield and an accompanying increase in the dodecane yield at high concentrations and a max- imum in the methylpyrene yield at an intermediate concentration.
In addition to capturing the qualitat- ive trends in the data, the model also provided good quantitative predictions of the dodecane and methyl- pyrene molar yields.

caption_text: The calculated rate being slower than the ex- perimental rate at high concentrations was also evi- dent in the neat pyrolysis results of Fig. 2. Figures 2 4, taken together, lead us to conclude that the detailed chemical kinetics model described herein did an adequate job of describing DOP pyroly- sis. Its qualitative predictions about the effects of time, temperature, and concentration were correct in all cases.

caption_text: To summarize, Fig. 5 shows that RHT from x-dodecylpyrene radicals and alkylhy- dropyrenyl radicals are the most important hydro- genolysis steps, and that RRD is also important because of its unique role as an initiation step. We explored the influence of the RHT steps further by excluding these reactions (steps 24 29, 32 36 in Fig. 1) from the model and then simulating DDP pyrolysis. All other reactions were retained, and the values of all rate constants remained unchanged.
raw_window: To summarize, Fig. 5 shows that RHT from x-dodecylpyrene radicals and alkylhy- dropyrenyl radicals are the most important hydro- genolysis steps, and that RRD is also important because of its unique role as an initiation step.
We explored the influence of the RHT steps further by excluding these reactions (steps 24 29, 32 36 in Fig. 1) from the model and then simulating DDP pyrolysis.
All other reactions were retained, and the values of all rate constants remained unchanged.

caption_text: Fig- ure 6 compares the predictions of this model without RHT steps with the experimental data shown pre- viously in Fig. 4. The model prediction, given by the solid line, tracks the data as well as the full model did at low concentrations. At higher concentrations, how- ever, the revised model fails to capture even the qualitative trends in the data The precipitous de- crease in ODP yield and the rapid formation of dodecane observed experimentally are not predicted.
raw_window: Fig- ure 6 compares the predictions of this model without RHT steps with the experimental data shown pre- viously in Fig. 4.
The model prediction, given by the solid line, tracks the data as well as the full model did at low concentrations.

At higher concentrations, how- ever, the revised model fails to capture even the qualitative trends in the data The precipitous de- crease in ODP yield and the rapid formation of dodecane observed experimentally are not predicted.

This mechanism for DDP is an extension of the long-chain n-alkylbenzene pyrolysis mechanism developed by Savage and Klein (1989) and the ethyl- pyrene pyrolysis mechanism recently developed by Smith and Savage (1992).
The key features of the mechanism are outlined in the following paragraphs.

caption_text: Table 3 lists the molar yield calculated for each of the products and radical intermediates from DDP neat pyrolysis at 400 C and 90 mm. Pyrene (Q4), dodecane (fl4H), and the internal olefin 12 (double bond between the a and /3 carbons) possess the highest yields.
raw_window: Table 3 lists the molar yield calculated for each of the products and radical intermediates from DDP neat pyrolysis at 400 C and 90 mm.
Pyrene (Q4), dodecane (fl4H), and the internal olefin 12 (double bond between the a and /3 carbons) possess the highest yields.
Pyrene and dodecane were the major products observed cx- perinientally, but high yields of the internal olefin were not reported for DDP pyrolysis (Savage et a!., 1989).
table_reason: S1 continues the description of the table content, while S2 introduces external information and context not part of the caption.

caption_text: Table 3 shows that the radicals P2 and p~ had molar yields at least an order of magnitude higher than the yield of any other radical. The high yield for the cc-DDP radical (P2) can be accounted for by noting that it is formed in the most rapid hydrogen abstrac- tion step, but it decomposes only through relatively slow /3-scission and RHT reaction steps.
raw_window: Table 3 shows that the radicals P2 and p~ had molar yields at least an order of magnitude higher than the yield of any other radical.

We will re- turn to the importance of the z-DDP radical in a sub- sequent section of this paper.

flOP (A), methylpyrene (fl,H), vinylpyrene (Q2), and pyrene (Q4) are representative of the key prod- ucts from DDP pyrolysis, so our discussion of the sensitivity analysis results will focus on these prod- ucts.
Inspection of Table 4 reveals that the calculated concentration of flOP is most strongly influenced by the rate constants for steps 3, 14, 2, and 37.

These steps are the two initiation steps by RRO, the transfer of hydrogen from a-DDP radicals to non-ipso positions on flOP, and the fission of a termination product into two a-DOP radicals.
Thus, these steps are the most important in determining DDP pyrolysis kinetics.

SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS (1) The detailed chemical kinetics model described in this paper is consistent with experimental observa- tions reported previously for DDP pyrolysis.

Therefore, we included only the termination reactions involving these rad- icals in the reduced mechanism.
